speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer a fool as his foolishness deserves,
So that he will not be wise in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who sends a message by the hand of a fool
Chops off his own feet and drinks violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like useless legs to one who cannot walk,
So is a proverb in the mouths of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like one who binds a stone in a sling,
So is one who gives honor to a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a thorn that sticks in the hand of a heavy drinker,
So is a proverb in the mouths of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an archer who wounds everyone,
So is one who hires a fool or hires those who pass by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a dog that returns to its vomit,
So is a fool who repeats his foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see a person wise in his own eyes?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy one says, “There is a lion on the road!
A lion is in the public square!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the door turns on its hinges,
So does a lazy one on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy one buries his hand in the dish;
He is weary of bringing it to his mouth again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy one is wiser in his own eyes
Than seven people who can give a discreet answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like one who takes a dog by the ears,
So is one who passes by and meddles with strife not belonging to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a maniac who shoots
Flaming arrows, arrows, and death,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So is a person who deceives his neighbor,
And says, “Was I not joking?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For lack of wood the fire goes out,
And where there is no gossiper, quarreling quiets down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire,
So is a contentious person to kindle strife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a gossiper are like dainty morsels,
And they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an earthenware vessel overlaid with silver impurities
Are burning lips and a wicked heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who hates disguises it with his lips,
But he harbors deceit in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he speaks graciously, do not believe him,
Because there are seven abominations in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though his hatred covers itself with deception,
His wickedness will be revealed in the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who digs a pit will fall into it,
And one who rolls a stone, it will come back on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lying tongue hates those it crushes,
And a flattering mouth works ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
For you do not know what a day may bring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let another praise you, and not your own mouth;
A stranger, and not your own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stone is heavy and the sand weighty,
But the provocation of a fool is heavier than both of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wrath is fierce and anger is a flood,
But who can stand before jealousy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is open rebuke
Than love that is concealed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Faithful are the wounds of a friend,
But deceitful are the kisses of an enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A satisfied person despises honey,
But to a hungry person any bitter thing is sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bird that wanders from its nest,
So is a person who wanders from his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oil and perfume make the heart glad,
And a person’s advice is sweet to his friend.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad,
So that I may reply to one who taunts me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prudent person sees evil and hides himself;
But the naive proceed, and pay the penalty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take his garment when he becomes a guarantor for a stranger;
And for a foreign woman seize a pledge from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who blesses his friend with a loud voice early in the morning,
It will be considered a curse to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A constant dripping on a day of steady rain
And a contentious woman are alike;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who would restrain her restrains the wind,
And grasps oil with his right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As iron sharpens iron,
So one person sharpens another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who tends the fig tree will eat its fruit,
And one who cares for his master will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As in water a face reflects the face,
So the heart of a person reflects the person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,
Nor are the eyes of a person ever satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crucible is for silver and the furnace for gold,
And each is tested by the praise accorded him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though you pound the fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain,
His foolishness still will not leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Know well the condition of your flocks,
And pay attention to your herds;
speaker: Narrator

text:
For riches are not forever,
Nor does a crown endure to all generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the grass disappears, the new growth is seen,
And the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lambs will be for your clothing,
And the goats will bring the price of a field,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And there will be enough goats’ milk for your food,
For the food of your household,
And sustenance for your attendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked flee when no one is pursuing,
But the righteous are bold as a lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Due to a wrongdoing of a land its leaders are many,
But by a person of understanding and knowledge, so it endures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor man who oppresses the helpless
Is like a driving rain which leaves no food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who abandon the Law praise the wicked,
But those who keep the Law strive against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people do not understand justice,
But those who seek the Lord understand everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a poor person who walks in his integrity,
Than a person who is crooked, though he is rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who keeps the Law is a discerning son,
But he who is a companion of gluttons humiliates his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who increases his wealth by interest of any kind,
Collects it for one who is gracious to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who turns his ear away from listening to the Law,
Even his prayer is an abomination.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who leads the upright astray in an evil way
Will himself fall into his own pit,
But the blameless will inherit good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich person is wise in his own eyes,
But the poor who has understanding sees through him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the righteous triumph, there is great glory,
But when the wicked rise, people hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who conceals his wrongdoings will not prosper,
But one who confesses and abandons them will find compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed is the person who fears always,
But one who hardens his heart will fall into disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a roaring lion and a rushing bear
Is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A leader who is a great oppressor lacks understanding,
But a person who hates unjust gain will prolong his days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who is burdened with the guilt of human blood
Will be a fugitive until death; no one is to support him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who walks blamelessly will receive help,
But one who is crooked will fall all at once.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who works his land will have plenty of food,
But one who follows empty pursuits will have plenty of poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A faithful person will abound with blessings,
But one who hurries to be rich will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To show partiality is not good,
Because for a piece of bread a man will do wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person with an evil eye hurries after wealth
And does not know that poverty will come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who rebukes a person will afterward find more favor
Than one who flatters with the tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who robs his father or his mother
And says, “There is no wrong done,”
Is the companion of a person who destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An arrogant person stirs up strife,
But one who trusts in the Lord will prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who trusts in his own heart is a fool,
But one who walks wisely will flee to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who gives to the poor will never lack anything,
But one who shuts his eyes will have many curses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked rise, people hide themselves;
But when they perish, the righteous increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person often rebuked who becomes obstinate
Will suddenly be broken beyond remedy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the righteous increase, the people rejoice,
But when a wicked person rules, people groan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man who loves wisdom makes his father glad,
But he who involves himself with prostitutes wastes his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king gives stability to the land by justice,
But a person who takes bribes ruins it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man who flatters his neighbor
Is spreading a net for his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By wrongdoing an evil person is ensnared,
But the righteous sings and rejoices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous is concerned for the rights of the poor;
The wicked does not understand such concern.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arrogant people inflame a city,
But wise people turn away anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a wise person has a controversy with a foolish person,
The foolish person either rages or laughs, and there is no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People of bloodshed hate the blameless person,
But the upright are concerned for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool always loses his temper,
But a wise person holds it back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a ruler pays attention to falsehood,
All his ministers become wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor person and the oppressor have this in common:
The Lord gives light to the eyes of both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a king judges the poor with truth,
His throne will be established forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rod and a rebuke give wisdom,
But a child who gets his own way brings shame to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked increase, wrongdoing increases;
But the righteous will see their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Correct your son, and he will give you comfort;
He will also delight your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where there is no vision, the people are unrestrained,
But happy is one who keeps the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A slave will not be instructed by words alone;
For though he understands, there will be no response.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see a person who is hasty with his words?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who pampers his slave from childhood
Will in the end find him to be rebellious.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An angry person stirs up strife,
And a hot-tempered person abounds in wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s pride will bring him low,
But a humble spirit will obtain honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is a partner with a thief hates his own life;
He hears the oath but tells nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of man brings a snare,
But one who trusts in the Lord will be protected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek the ruler’s favor,
But justice for mankind comes from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An unjust person is an abomination to the righteous,
And one who is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, the pronouncement.
The man declares to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am certainly more stupid than any man,
And I do not have the understanding of a man;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nor have I learned wisdom,
Nor do I have the knowledge of the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has ascended into heaven and descended?
Who has gathered the wind in His fists?
Who has wrapped the waters in His garment?
Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is His name or His Son’s name?
Surely you know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every word of God is pure;
He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not add to His words
Or He will rebuke you, and you will be proved a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Two things I have asked of You;
Do not refuse me before I die:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So that I will not be full and deny You and say, “Who is the Lord?”
And that I will not become impoverished and steal,
And profane the name of my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not slander a slave to his master,
Or he will curse you and you will be found guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a kind of person who curses his father
And does not bless his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a kind who is pure in his own eyes,
Yet is not washed from his filthiness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a kind—oh how lofty are his eyes!
And his eyelids are raised in arrogance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a kind of person whose teeth are like swords
And his jaw teeth like knives,
To devour the poor from the earth
And the needy from among mankind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The leech has two daughters:
“Give” and “Give.”
There are three things that will not be satisfied,
Four that will not say, “Enough”:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol, the infertile womb,
Earth that is never satisfied with water,
And fire that never says, “Enough.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that mocks a father
And scorns a mother,
The ravens of the valley will pick it out,
And the young eagles will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things which are too wonderful for me,
Four which I do not understand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the eagle in the sky,
The way of a snake on a rock,
The way of a ship in the middle of the sea,
And the way of a man with a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the way of an adulterous woman:
She eats and wipes her mouth,
And says, “I have done no wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under three things the earth quakes,
And under four, it cannot endure:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under a slave when he becomes king,
And a fool when he is satisfied with food,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under an unloved woman when she gets a husband,
And a female servant when she dispossesses her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Four things are small on the earth,
But they are exceedingly wise:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ants are not a strong people,
But they prepare their food in the summer;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rock hyraxes are not a mighty people,
Yet they make their houses in the rocks;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The locusts have no king,
Yet all of them go out in ranks;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lizard you may grasp with the hands,
Yet it is in kings’ palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things which are stately in their march,
Even four which are stately when they walk:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lion, which is mighty among animals
And does not retreat from anything,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strutting rooster or the male goat,
And a king when his army is with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have been foolish in exalting yourself,
Or if you have plotted evil, put your hand on your mouth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: The words of King Lemuel, the pronouncement which his mother taught him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
What, my son?
And what, son of my womb?
And what, son of my vows?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not give your strength to women,
Or your ways to that which destroys kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not for kings, Lemuel,
It is not for kings to drink wine,
Or for rulers to desire intoxicating drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise they will drink and forget what is decreed,
And pervert the rights of all the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give intoxicating drink to one who is perishing,
And wine to one whose life is bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him drink and forget his poverty,
And remember his trouble no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your mouth for the people who cannot speak,
For the rights of all the unfortunate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your mouth, judge righteously,
And defend the rights of the poor and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An excellent wife, who can find her?
For her worth is far above jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart of her husband trusts in her,
And he will have no lack of gain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She does him good and not evil
All the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She looks for wool and linen,
And works with her hands in delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is like merchant ships;
She brings her food from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And she rises while it is still night
And gives food to her household,
And portions to her attendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She considers a field and buys it;
From her earnings she plants a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She surrounds her waist with strength
And makes her arms strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She senses that her profit is good;
Her lamp does not go out at night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She stretches out her hands to the distaff,
And her hands grasp the spindle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She extends her hand to the poor,
And she stretches out her hands to the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is not afraid of the snow for her household,
For all her household are clothed with scarlet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes coverings for herself;
Her clothing is fine linen and purple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband is known in the gates,
When he sits among the elders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes linen garments and sells them,
And supplies belts to the tradesmen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strength and dignity are her clothing,
And she smiles at the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She opens her mouth in wisdom,
And the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She watches over the activities of her household,
And does not eat the bread of idleness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her children rise up and bless her;
Her husband also, and he praises her, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Many daughters have done nobly,
But you excel them all.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain,
But a woman who fears the Lord, she shall be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give her the product of her hands,
And let her works praise her in the gates.
speaker: Narrator
